learning_outcomes.description: Have a basic understanding of the history of some historical and contemporary expressions of the supernatural.
Understand fundamental aspects of the academic study of religion.
Express and understand your own worldview and its impact on your understanding of issues more clearly.
Appreciate the diversity of views about the supernatural.
Express coherent opinions on the role of the supernatural in historical and contemporary culture.

assessments.task_description:
Students will be expected to complete 10 journal entries over the course of the semester, following the lectures of Weeks 2 onward, for a total of 10 journals. Each journal entry must be submitted within one week of lectures, and they must be submitted via journal Turnitin links on the Blackboard page. Each entry should take its topic from questions that will be listed on Blackboard that will be based upon the week's readings. When more than one question is listed, students should select only one of the options to respond to. Entries must be 200 words long (+/- 10%). The window for completing a journal entry opens on the day of the lecture to which the entry pertains and closes one week later, at the start of the next lecture. Therefore, it is important to maintain a consistent effort for this task over the semester.


A maximum of 10 marks will be awarded for journal entries (1 mark per journal entry), if entries are completed on time, and demonstrate preparation (mainly though knowledge of readings). If only 5 or fewer journal entries are completed, the student will receive 0 journal entry marks.


Journal assignments begin in Week 2, for 10 weeks. Entries are due before the start of the next lecture.

This assessment task evaluates students' abilities, skills and knowledge without the aid of generative Artificial Intelligence (AI). Students are advised that the use of AI technologies to develop responses is strictly prohibited and may constitute student misconduct under the Student Code of Conduct.
assessments.submission_guidelines: The assessment must be submitted via Turnitin on the Blackboard page.
assessments.deferral_or_extension: You cannot defer or apply for an extension for this assessment.
assessments.late_submission: You will receive a mark of 0 if this assessment is submitted late.
assessments.additional_info: You cannot defer or apply for an extension for this assessment.

assessments.assessment_title: Generative AI Scaffolding Writing Assignment I
assessments.task_description:
This scaffolding assignment requires that you read the instructions for each section, and complete the tasks using a combination of AI-generated content and your own responses. This assignment purposefully incorporates the use of generative AI, where indicated. The assignment is designed to help you develop critical thinking and academic writing skills, particularly in the context of evaluating and utilising AI-generated material.

The assignment must be submitted as a Word document, and not submitted as a PDF or any other file type. Submitting in a non-Word file type will result in a -10% penalty. Do not rely on Grade Centre in Blackboard for your results. Look at your assessment grade and feedback in Turnitin.

Word count: 1,200 words. NOTE: The word count limit isn't a hard and fast cap that students need to reach. Please note that the overall word count has to include all sections, except for those made up of bibliographic information (sections II and X). Those other sections include sections III and IV, even though they don't have explicit word limits. It's difficult to put word limits on sections III and IV, because a thesis statement may be one or two sentences, while some students may write a little bit more than other students in section IV, or they may go over in sections V-IX. So, the remaining words, depending on how much students put in the other word-limited sections, are associated with sections III and IV, or could be some buffer if they go over in other sections.

Sections III and IV: ~200

Critique of AI-generated Introductory Paragraph: ~150-200

Critique of AI-generated Argument Paragraph 1: 200

Critique of AI-generated Argument Paragraph 2: 200

Critique of AI-generated Argument Paragraph 3: 200

Critique of AI-generated Concluding Paragraph: 150-200

Total: ~1,200

AGAIN: Do not rely on Grade Centre in Blackboard for your results. Look at your assessment grade and feedback in Turnitin.

This assignment purposefully incorporates the use of generative AI, where indicated. Artificial Intelligence (AI) provides emerging tools that support students in completing this assessment task. Students may appropriately use AI in completing this assessment task, where its use is indicated. A failure to reference generative AI use in the sections where AI-use is not permitted may constitute student misconduct under the Student Code of Conduct.
assessments.submission_guidelines: The assessment must be submitted via Turnitin on the Blackboard page. The assignment must be submitted as a Word document, and not submitted as a PDF or any other file type. Submitting in a non-Word file type will result in a -10% penalty.
assessments.deferral_or_extension: You may be able to apply for an extension.
assessments.late_submission: A penalty of 10% of the maximum possible mark will be deducted per 24 hours from time submission is due for up to 7 days. After 7 days, you will receive a mark of 0.
assessments.additional_info: You may be able to apply for an extension.

assessments.assessment_title: Generative AI Scaffolding Writing Assignment II
assessments.task_description:
This scaffolding assignment requires that you read the instructions for each section, and complete the tasks using a combination of AI-generated content and your own responses. This assignment purposefully incorporates the use of generative AI, where indicated. The assignment is designed to help you develop critical thinking and academic writing skills, particularly in the context of evaluating and utilising AI-generated material.

The assignment must be submitted as a Word document, and not submitted as a PDF or any other file type. Submitting in a non-Word file type will result in a -10% penalty.

Word count: 2,000 words. NOTE: The word count limit isn't a hard and fast cap that students need to reach. Please note that the overall word count has to include all sections, except for those made up of bibliographic information (sections II and X). Those other sections include sections III and IV, even though they don't have explicit word limits. It's difficult to put work limits on sections III and IV, because a thesis statement may be one or two sentences, while some students may write a little bit more than other students in section IV, or they may go over in sections V-IX. So, the remaining 500–750 words, depending on how much students put in the other word-limited sections, are associated with sections III and IV, or could be some buffer if they go over in other sections.

Sections III and IV: 500-750

Critique of AI-generated Introductory Paragraph: 250-300

Critique of AI-generated Argument Paragraph 1: 250-300

Critique of AI-generated Argument Paragraph 2: 250-300

Critique of AI-generated Argument Paragraph 3: 250-300

Critique of AI-generated Concluding Paragraph: 250-300

Total: ~2000

AGAIN: Do not rely on Grade Centre in Blackboard for your results. Look at your assessment grade and feedback in Turnitin.

This assignment purposefully incorporates the use of generative AI, where indicated. Artificial Intelligence (AI) provides emerging tools that support students in completing this assessment task. Students may appropriately use AI in completing this assessment task, where its use is indicated. A failure to reference generative AI use in the sections where AI-use is not permitted may constitute student misconduct under the Student Code of Conduct.
assessments.submission_guidelines: The assessment must be submitted via Turnitin on the Blackboard page. The assignment must be submitted as a Word document, and not submitted as a PDF or any other file type. Submitting in a non-Word file type will result in a -10% penalty.
assessments.deferral_or_extension: You may be able to apply for an extension.
assessments.late_submission: A penalty of 10% of the maximum possible mark will be deducted per 24 hours from time submission is due for up to 7 days. After 7 days, you will receive a mark of 0.
assessments.additional_info: You may be able to apply for an extension.

learning_activities.topic:
The Supernatural is What?

Required Reading: Jindra, Michael. Natural/Supernatural Conceptions in Western Cultural Contexts. Anthropological Forum, 13:2 (2003): 159-166. Extension Readings: Legare, Evans, E. M., Rosengren, K. S., & Harris, P. L. (2012). "The Coexistence of Natural and Supernatural Explanations Across Cultures and Development." Child Development, 83(3), 779 793.


Learning outcomes: L01, L02, L04

"The Coexistence of Natural and Supernatural Explanations Across Cultures and Development." Child Development , 83(3), 779 793.

learning_activities.topic:
Religious Disenchantment?

Of Ghosts and Spirites Walking by Night, in The Penguin Book of the Undead, edited by Scott Bruce, 221-231. Penguin, 2016; Taillepied, Noel. When Night Draws Swiftly Darkling On, in The Penguin Book of the Undead, edited by Scott Bruce, 232-237. Penguin, 2016.


Learning outcomes: L01, L02, L04
